questions.description: Too slow cooling of food is a very common reason for food poisoning. Cooling should happen quickly (in under 4 hours) so that the microbes in the food can not reproduce and grow into large hazardous quantities. During cooling food has a dangerous temperature (between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius) where microbes reproduce very quickly.

questions.question: Microbes are only found in places which are visibly dirty.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, not only in dirty locations. However it is probable that dirty spots contain more microbes than clean ones.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear their work outfit when going outside of the food production area during e.g. their lunch break.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is not a food poisoning causing bacteria. BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Domestic water pollution is often caused by human faeces.
questions.description: Norovirus and Campylobacter enter the domestic water supply mainly through municipal wastewater, and Campylobacter also through animal faeces. Inadequate dosing of disinfectant chemicals can also cause contamination.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Pasteurizing destroys all bacteria from a food product.
questions.description: During pasteurization the food product is heated to +degrees celsius. This temperature destroys a large percentage of microbes, but the product still requires cold storage. For example pasteurized milk must be kept at a temperature of +6 degrees or less.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: Food products can not be sold nor used after the last use-by-date.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The marking must be based upon research results of lastingness.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can not reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Open cartons of long-life (UHT) milk and pasteurised milk are stored in the same way.
questions.description: Open cartons of long-life (UHT) milk and pasteurised milk are kept in cold storage.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. an online store sselling food products, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Earth can contain lots of food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Earthy vegetables must be treated and stored such that the earth does not spread onto other food products.

questions.question: Pasteurizing and ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) mean the same thing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: Viruses can spread into food products by the hands.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing microbes can stay on the skin of the hands e.g. after going to the toilet if the hands have not been properly washed. The microbes can later spread from the hands onto unpacked food products or into work areas.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Disinfecting work surfaces does not compensate for regular, careful washing.
questions.description: Work surfaces must be cleaned and washed regularly after each phase of work, and disinfecting can improve the overall cleaning result.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: Moulds and yeasts can reproduce in more acidized environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Most bacteria reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Moulds and yeasts can reproduce on a very broad pH zone, including products with acidity.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: Own-check plans help to lessen the amount of food products that is unfit or needs to be gotten rid of.
questions.description: By law, merchants are required to identify and list critical points in food product preparation and handling to do with food product rules, and to also take action to make sure these points are monitored regularly. When possible problems are taken notice of in time, the amount of food products that are unfit and need to be gotten rid of will become smaller.

questions.question: If canned foods are not sterilized properly, the food can be dangerous for the human health.
questions.description: The cans of canned food can contain spores of clostridium botulinum if the food is not sterilized properly. This spore can create dangerous toxins in the product.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: A dirty hand washing area is a risk for hand hygiene.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed smoked fish does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing. However, the products can still contain microbes that can survive without oxygen.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: Indoor plants can spread harmful microbes to food products.
questions.description: Indoor plants must not be kept in food product preparation areas because microbes live on their surface and in their earth.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: Thoroughly boiled food does not contain any microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: Even in small cafs the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: The HACCP system is used to help own-check plans and the planning of them.
questions.description: HACCP, meaning the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points system, helps to think of critical points during transportation of food products from preparation to consumers. Explaining these critical points in the own-check plan helps upkeeping good work hygiene.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: The norovirus is destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: If there are any problems in temperature or sensory quality of delivered food products, a spoken report to one's supervisor is sufficient.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities in temperature or sensory quality of delivered easily perishable products must always be logged in the own-check plan forms.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: The slow cooling of food is one of the main causes of food poisoning.
questions.description: The slower food is cooled to under 8 degrees Celsius, the longer food poisoning causing microbes have time to reproduce quickly in optimal conditions. Food should be cooled to under 8 degrees in under 4 hours. When preparing large amounts of food at the same time, the cooling can take too long.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives will also spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes. In the European Union all allowed preservatives have an E-code.

questions.question: An entire carrot spoils faster than a grated carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in Karelian pasties kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Karelian pasties are usually filled with rice porridge boiled in milk. Easily perishable food products, such as Karelian pasties, must be kept in cool temperatures. In room temperature the bacteria in pasties will reproduce quicker.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Salt can not contain microbes.
questions.description: Salt is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is not done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Food products must be traceable, i.e. it must be possible, if necessary, to prove from where the raw materials were obtained.
questions.description: Traceability is used to prove from where the raw materials were obtained and to where the finished products have been delivered.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed during sterilization.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: All easily perishable food products must be stored in temperatures under 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: This statement is correct, but one must notice that raw mince meat requires a storing temperature of at most 4 degrees Celsius, and fish and shellfish even while vacuum-packed must be stored between 0 and 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use a cloth towel.
questions.description: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use disposable hand towels.

questions.question: Waste bins can be placed in the dry food storage room if there is no other place for them.
questions.description: The waste management of food premises must be arranged so that waste and food products do not come into contact with each other.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: The more microbes there are in a cleaning cloth, the worse it smells.
questions.description: Microbes are usually odourless microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: If one's hands have been carefully washed then food products can be handled with hands.
questions.description: Clean equipment should always be used instead of hands, no matter how well washed, whenever possible.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: Food control authorities are responsible for monitoring companies' own-check plans.
questions.description: The responsibility of own-check plans is the company's. Officials have a possibility to get to know companies' own-check plans and data while doing checks. However, own-check plan documents are companies' personal documents and the companies have the responsibility of storing them and training any personnel to act according to the own-check plan.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: A best-before-date must be marked on easily perishable products.
questions.description: Easily perishable products must have a use-by-date.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Guide dogs are not allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: Cold-stored root vegetables may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Root vegetables that are cold stored for a long time may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is not a food poisoning causing bacteria. BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear their work outfit when going outside of the food production area during e.g. their lunch break.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Pizza toppings do not need to be cold stored because pizzas are baked in a very hot oven.
questions.description: Perishable food products that require cold storage must always be cold stored.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for people with a weakened immune system.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain pathogens (disease-causing bacteria.) The most important bacteria that can cause danger to food safety in raw milk are EHEC, listeria, salmonella and campylo bacteria.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2C).

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: Boxes meant for transporting food can be stored outside if there is no space indoors.
questions.description: Food transportation boxes must be stored in an area where they do not get dirty. Restaurant and transportation companies agree on the frequency of collection and cleaning of boxes and trolleys.

questions.question: If you drop a steak onto the floor, you can use it as long as you fry it.
questions.description: A steak that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: In vegetables, only perished areas that can be noticed visually are health hazards.
questions.description: Due to cultivation and treatments the surface of vegetables can have impurities which can not be seen with the bare eye. Harmful microbes can also be on areas that are not visually perished. Vegetables are a health risk when they are not washed properly before use.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Food products must be cooled first by using separate cooling equipment and only then moved into a freezer for storage.
questions.description: Products that are not frozen and are placed into a freezer will raise the temperature of the freezer; this weakens the lastingness of the products in the freezer.

questions.question: Hand washing sinks can be used for cleaning root vegetables.
questions.description: Enough hand washing areas must be available, and they must only be used for washing hands.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed when products are boiled (+100 degrees Celsius).
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: Beer is not produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she must not handle food products.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it does not have to say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: Bacteria spores will stay alive even when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: Carrots covered with soil do not contain harmful microbes because soil is a pure natural product.
questions.description: Many microbes are part of the normal microbial growth in soil, which means that carrots covered in soil contain microbes.

questions.question: Milk spoils faster than sour milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Unpacked raw fish must always be stored separate from other food products.
questions.description: Raw fish must be stored separately from other food products to prevent the risk of cross-contamination.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: When a health inspector inspects a workplace, he or she will also check the workplace's own check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Ice cubes cannot contain harmful microbes, because their temperature is so low.
questions.description: Ice cubes can contain harmful microbes if the ice cube machine or the ice cube container hasn't been properly cleaned. The water used for producing the ice cubes has to meet the standards for clean drinking water.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Optimal temperature means the temperature where microbes reproduce the slowest.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, is always a very weak food poisoning.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: Beneficial bacteria usually make it harder for harmful bacteria to grow.
questions.description: Harmful bacteria have to compete with beneficial bacteria for living space and nutrition. Beneficial bacteria can change living conditions in food products, e.g. the acidity, such that it becomes worse for harmful bacteria and makes them grow slower or not at all.

questions.question: It is important to use cleaning methods that remove dust efficiently when cleaning food premises.
questions.description: Cleaning methods that remove dust efficiently are used for cleaning food premises. Surface dust can be effectively removed by vacuuming and wiping surfaces with a microfibre cloth or a damp towel.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Foreign raspberries may be used for making food if the product will be kept well refrigerated.
questions.description: Foreign raspberies must always be properly heated by boiling before serving. Using non-heated foreign rasberries creates a risk of listeria.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: The cooling of food products should be done by using cooling cabinets (chillers).
questions.description: Only cooling cabinets can ensure sufficiently fast and effective cooling.

questions.question: The ice kept in transport cases for fresh fish must meet the purity requirements.
questions.description: Ice used with food products must only be made of water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: A product can not be used for food preparation after the product's best-before date.
questions.description: Best before dates tell that the product's main attributes and characteristics will remain the same up to the marked date, as long as it is stored correctly. The product can be used and sold after the best before date. The usability and quality of the product can be checked using the senses (visually etc.) after the best before date.

questions.question: Food products must be traceable, i.e. it must be possible, if necessary, to prove from where the raw materials were obtained.
questions.description: Traceability is used to prove from where the raw materials were obtained and to where the finished products have been delivered.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Bacteria spores die when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: When frozen vegetables are thawed at room temperature, the number of harmful microbes in them increases rapidly.
questions.description: When food products are thawed at room temperature, the risk of microbial growth on the surface of the product increases even before the inner part is thawed.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes only inside the food production area.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Kitchen staff do not need to remove jewellery made of precious metal because precious metal is not a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wearing jewellery is always a hygiene hazard. Dirt can accumulate under a ring, and a piece of jewellery or part of it can also come off and end up in food.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: If a food authority representative wants to see your own-check plan, you must present it to him/her.
questions.description: If a food authority representative wants to see an operator's own-check plan, the operator is obliged to present it.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Blanching improves the lastingness of for example vegetables when they are stored in freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means quick boiling, stops enzymic activity on the surface of vegetables by destroying microbe activity. This way vegetables do not dry on the surface while freezing them. Blanching can also be used for example to get rid of naturally occuring toxins in morel mushrooms to make them edible. In this case blanching is done many times and the boiling water is changed between boilings.

questions.question: Hepatitis A can spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Even in small cafs the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Thoroughly boiled food does not contain any microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: If an employee gets a small wound on his or her hand, it is enough to protect it with a bandage.
questions.description: A bandage alone is not enough. A single-use glove should also be worn on the hand; this prevents water from entering the wound.

questions.question: Wastebins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Frozen fish is thawed on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: Frozen food products are always thawed in a cold room.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it must say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: A food product can only be a health hazard if it has a contaminated area that is visible to the naked eye.
questions.description: Growth on the surfaces of food products caused by moulds and yeasts are visible to the naked eye, but microbes are usually microorganisms that are not visible to the naked eye.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she can still work with food products if single-use protective gloves are used.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: The gutting and proper washing of fish is enough to prevent tapeworm infections.
questions.description: Infectious tapeworm larvas can be inside the muscles or roe of the fish. Tapeworm infections can be prevented by cooking or freezing the fish or roe.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Food product employees can use wedding and engagement rings while handling easily perishable goods.
questions.description: Jewellery can not be used when working with food products. No matter how well hands are washed, a large amount of harmful microbes can stay under rings and can later contaminate food products being handled.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed in the food premises storeroom if the employer allows it.
questions.description: Smoking is prohibited in the food premises in those areas where food is prepared, sold, processed or stored.

questions.question: Hepatitis A can spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is not to manage food-related health hazards.
questions.description: One of the most important objectives of the own-check plan is to manage food-related health hazards.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: The shelf life of food products can be extended by irradiating them.
questions.description: Only dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings are allowed to be irradiated. The purpose of irradiation is to eliminate bacteria and insects as well as to prevent the product from sprouting, for example.

questions.question: Cleaning rags must be changed regularly.
questions.description: The hygiene of cleaning rags in areas with food products is very important. The rags must be washed and changed regularly so that they will not spread food poisoning bacteria or microbes.

questions.question: Plastic wrappers for food packaging can be stored outdoors, protected from rain.
questions.description: Plastic and paper wrappers for packing food are stored in a clean indoor space. Packaging materials must be stored sufficiently far away from contaminating materials such as waste or food.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: All cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: Own-check plans require to monitor the temperature of cold storage equipment. If the equipment does not thermometers, the monitoring is impossible to do.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria.
questions.description: The cause of food poisoning can, in addition to bacteria, also be a virus, mould fungus or protozoan.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold because the protective gas protects the products from perishing.
questions.description: Food products stored in packages with protective gas must always be stored in the cold according to the instructions on the packaging. Protective gas packages have normal air changed into air that contains little or no oxygen to prevent microbes that use oxygen from reproducing. Protective gas prevents e.g. the surface of meat from darkening and thus keeps the product sensually appealling.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Own-check plans must also include e.g. cleaning and waste disposal procedures.
questions.description: Own-check plans must, along with microbiological risks, consider the hygiene of personnel, cleaning, receival of products and actions to be done when pests have been noticed.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: If a food authority representative wants to see your own-check plan, you must present it to him/her.
questions.description: If a food authority representative wants to see an operator's own-check plan, the operator is obliged to present it.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the caf, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: An entire carrot spoils faster than a grated carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Liquid soap is to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Liquid soap is hygienic. The dispenser of the liquid soap should be one which can be pressed with the forearm instead of the hands.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) can be stored in soda bottles.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Optimal temperature means the temperature where microbes reproduce the slowest.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to handle unpacked food products is to use wooden utensils.
questions.description: The most hygienic utensils for handling unpacked food products are made of plastic or steel.

questions.question: Food products must be traceable, i.e. it must be possible, if necessary, to prove from where the raw materials were obtained.
questions.description: Traceability is used to prove from where the raw materials were obtained and to where the finished products have been delivered.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: Ice cube machines do not need to be cleaned separately, because their low temperature prevents microbes from multiplying.
questions.description: Ice cube machines must be cleaned just as regularly and carefully as other cooling equipment.

questions.question: Most microbes grow poorly when the pH is close to neutral (pH 7).
questions.description: Most microbes grow best in neutral pH conditions, in the pH range from 6.6 to 7.5.

questions.question: The monitoring logs made for own-check plans, e.g. logs of temperature measurements, must be stored at the workplace for 6 months.
questions.description: Logs must be stored for at least 1 year after selling a product. The information included can be used to trace errors and problems.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: If worktops look clean, they are definitely clean.
questions.description: Microbes are microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Large central kitchens and small cafs have the same own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces must design their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The acitivities, products and customers are different in small cafs and large kitchens. The own-check plans of large kitchens must be more precise and also more broad.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Vinegar lowers the pH value of a product and in this way makes the product last better.
questions.description: Especially the growth of bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.
